text: VARIOUS EXTRA CLOSE-UPS of this luxurious patchwork of  brilliant greens:
pops up from the ground and begins to water the already d soaked lawn.
No mother in sight, cruise through the thrushes.
At the bottom of a water hazard.

After a neat they sway, revealing the barren desert that  surrounds the artificial oasis. The sun already bakes the air. We hear the opening guitar strains of the Kim Deal-K Cobain suet of "WHAT I DID FOR LOVE," as we CRANE DOWN th palms to A BRAND-NEW TITLEIST 3 BALL. Just on the edge of the rough. A pair of yellow trousers  moves in. An iron confidently addresses the ball, and chi it out. The trousers walk out after it.
Digging dirt out of the grooves of the iron's face with a golf tee, while on the way to the green. Both hands are  gloved, instead of one, and the gloves are black.

In a squat over the ball, sizing up the curvy, fifty-foot journey to the hole. The figure positions himself and the putter above the ball, then pops the ball lightly. The ba rolls and bobs with purpose toward the hole, dodging haza and finding lanes, until it finally falls off of the gree and into the hole.

Sets the ball on the next tee. The figure moves to a leat golf bag. The hands pull the wipe rag off of the top of t bag and drop it on the ground, reach into the bag, drawin out a compact SNIPER RIFLE, affixed with a long silencer. The figure drops one knee down onto the rag, the other fo firmly setting its spikes. We move the figure to see the  face of the sniper, concentrating down the scope in his h squat. He is MARTIN BLANK. We SWING AROUND behind his head to look down the barrel w him. Four-hundred yards away, on another part of the cour another green is barely visible through groves of trees a rough. Three miniscule, SILVER-HAIRED FIGURES come into v One of them, in a RED SWEATER sets up for first putt. He  could be an investment banker, or an arms trader.
Flinches, and a low THUNK reports from the rifle. A secon later in the distance, the
Seems to vanish from his shoulders into a crimson mist. H body crumples to the green.
Returns the rifle to the bag, pulls out a driver, moves t the tee and whacks the ball. He watches its path and whis absently...
Hooked it.

The outdoor post-golf luncheon area of an elite Texas gol club. Martin sits in on the fringes of a conversation bet a group of executive types. CLUB MEMBER #1 has a Buddha-l peace in his eyes through the philosophical talk.
I'd come to the realization that  everything I'd based my life on was  false. And that my life had no  meaning.
(to Martin)
He gets this way when he hits over  eighty-five.
It seemed like my life was slipping  away, somehow. I was a knot in the  middle of a wet rope. Everything was  futile and nothing had value.

That's the way life is. The only  meaning and value is what we create.  Through structure, and discipline.  Though they seem to limit our freedom,  they actually give us great comfort.  Your problem is you're looking for  some great answer. Some ultimate  truth. When what you really should  do is go to work and go home.
And take golf lessons.

That's a tragedy. Can I finish my  story please? I began my search for  meaning. I was a Catholic, Jew,  Scientologist, Sufi, Buddhist. I  went to a Psychologist, psychiatrist,  herbalist, nutritionist, a shaman,  and a psychic. And they all pretty  much say the same stuff.
A Jew, a shaman, and a herbalist are  telling you the same thing? You're  insane.
Basically the same thing. In a very  evolved, esoteric way.
Insane.
To make a long story short...
--Thank God--

...at last I found the holistic system  of systems that opened up the doors  of heaven for me right here on earth.  And everyday I see the world through  the eyes of a child. A world of  creation and wonder.
Jesus...
Overflowing with love.
Tell me about it. Club Member #1 turns to Martin.

P.P.P. Personal Pan Power. All the  secrets of your universe are divided  up into eight easily digestible  slices. Club Member #1 pulls a laminated card from his wallet and hands it over to Martin. In the distance, sirens begin to wail.
See, see. It's in the accessible and  everyday shape of a pan pizza. Each  day you have a little slice of  peace...
A pizza-shaped diagram showing six "sections".
Oh I see. You got your individual  slices of hope, dignity, confidence,  self-love, justice, and harmony.
You open 'em up and there's the  sayings, stories, little bites of  insight. It's the P.P.P. Six Day  Week.
So you eat-- read it everyday?
Yes.
And these pan pizzas have opened up  the doors to heaven?
Correct. (re: the card)
That's for you. Keep it. Sirens are getting louder, closer to the club.
The source of the sirens are almost upon us. Martin walks toward his rented Town Car as the VALET pulls it up. He m the Valet by the trunk, where he trades tip for keys.

He fishes out the laminated "Personal  Pan Power" card, looks at it, and  tosses it onto the ground. Police  cars, now visible in the distance,  wind into the long club driveway.  Martin gets into his car and pulls  away.
As it lays on the asphalt. The wheel of a police car roll to a stop on it.

Martin sits in a first class seat, the tray table flipped down. On the left side of the tray is a stack of magazine of all kinds - Sports Illustrated, Mademoiselle, Wired,  Rolling Stone, National Review, Spin, National Geographic and on. He draws one off the top, and flips through it,  impassively taking in images and reading nothing. When he done with one, he discards it into the empty seat next to him and draws another-- Martin's way of instantly and  massively uploading the world around him: Toothless hockey player in triumph, Sony product parade,  crouched starving child with vulture in the background,  supermodel in suede, Tic Tacs, living former Presidents, in arm, smiling, etc.
The livery weaves out of the arrival lanes at Kennedy air Martin reclines in the back seat, a conversation having  already begun.
How was your day, today, sir?
Effective. But to tell you the truth,  I've lost my passion for work.
Do you like the people you work with?
I work alone.

That's it then. That's it. I've always  been alone. That's why I'm a good  driver. I can handle it. See, I can  think on my feet. I survive, I'm a  thinker. And I can sit there in front  of your house for two hours and it  don't bother me. Some people can't  do it! Some people are ranting and  raving, "Tell them fuckin' people to  get out here and get in this car, I  can't-- I want a go!" Where you gonna  go? You're gonna wind up back in  your garage at seven o'clock at night.  You ain't going nowhere. You leave  your house in the morning you get  back to your house in the evening.  What's the big deal, right?
You understand the psychology of the  job.
I do. Some guys can't adjust to it;  they can't handle it.
The car cuts through the upper east side. Martin and the  Driver exchange looks through the rear-view mirror.
You look like you're far away. Far  away and thinking about other things.  I'm right about that, aren't I?
No.
Well, let's just say that sometimes  I'm right. Sometimes you are.
Sometimes I am. Sometimes. It's only  natural.
(laughs to himself at  this great truth)
It's only natural.... The Driver pauses for dramatic emphasis
I been looking at you, and I've  decided that I want to share something  with you.
Okay.
Because your problem is you're bored.  And you have a very big mind. (beat)
I am part of what I call a brain  syndicate. No reaction from Martin.

I am part of a network of minds, a  group of five people who are all  connected, over hundreds, even  thousands of miles, through the mind.  We can think with each other, think  for each other. I can be driving  somewhere, sleeping with a woman--  whatever it is-- and at the same  time be thinking a thought in someone  else's mind, far away. Running someone  else's brain.
(indicates)
Up on the right.
And when you think of it, it's not  so surprising that a small group of  people control the whole world, is  it?

A sedate and well-appointed four-star suite on the Upper  East Side. Martin stands in front of one of the open wind watching the canopied entrance of an elegant high-rise ac the street. He lifts an eye rinse cup to his eye and tilt it back. A cellular phone RINGS, interrupting him. He mov to the desk and draws one of three phones from his briefc depresses a scrambler module, flips it open, and listens a moment.
If it's not there, I can't proceed.  Tell them. Martin hangs up. Picks up another phone and dials. As he  waits for an answer, he goes to a Fed Ex blueprint tube l on the bed.
Tom. I've been waiting for an answer.  I'm only in town tonight. He breaks the shipping seal and pulls out a series of fin metal parts including a long thin barrel, a scope, and a  silencer.
What's different this time than the  last time? I have to be down front...
Martin stands in front of the window, phone in one hand, scope in the other. Next to him, the assembled rifle rest across the arm of a chair.

...I don't bother to call anyone  else because you always take care of  me. He glances over to a second window to his left, which off a view further down the street. He goes to it. He raises scope and sees

A few blocks down, small even through the high-powered sc is your average BICYCLE MESSENGER dressed in lycra racing gear, weaving through traffic toward us. Slung low across his right hip is a black canvas bag. The Messenger's hand hidden in it. The other phone begins to RING.
Hold on a second, Tom. I got my hands  full here. He sets down the phone and answers the other, still watch the messenger.

Good. Account number 3649367, transfer  to account number 96-546-38739-47825.  Ask for Mr. Sanchez, tell him it's  Mr. Duckman. If there are any  problems, access file 673594638-IO- 98, and look at it. Martin drops the phone and moves away from Window #2 to t rifle. He mounts the scope and he looks out Window #1 at high-rise.
Of a DOORMAN opening the door for a group of five men in  suits. Four BODYGUARDS form a perimeter around the fifth  man, a mall, avuncular figure in his forties dressed in  Saville Row finery.
Takes a step back into the shadows of the room, and raise the rifle toward Window #2.
of an empty street. The bicycle messenger flashes past.
concentrating, tracks the path of the Messenger, leading left to right across the blind spot of the hotel room wal between Window #2 and Window #1.

the bicycle Messenger bears down on the group of men, dra a Mac-10 submachine gun from his bag. The group see him-- just as Martin's sniper FIRE explodes the Messenger's che Two of the Bodyguards collapse onto their boss. The other two open fire on the Messenger as he wipes out horribly i a parked car in front of them.
withdraws from the window, and picks up the phone again a begins to break down the rifle.
Sorry Tom. But look, I know it's the  playoffs. That's why I'm offering a  thousand dollars for one seat... Martin listens patiently as he works.
unbuttoning his double-breasted long coat.
just finishes packing.
...Well let me ask you, Tom. What do  I have to do to get courtside tickets  for the Knicks...?
The two bodyguards kick at the Messenger's body. The othe two begin to move off of their boss, who rises cowering. Doorman stands behind it all, unbuttoning his coat.

a tall, dark, sharp-featured man in his forties, wearing handlebar moustache. He moves toward the group of men as flips open his coat back over two huge chrome .44 Magnum  Charthouse Bulldog revolvers and OPENS FIRE on them.
is closing his bag when he hears the gun-thunder.
Never mind. I gotta go. Martin drops the phone, grabs his scope, and spins to the window.
of the Doorman kicking through the pile of dead bodyguard He gets to the man at the bottom-- their boss. The Doorma FIRES both guns.
reacts, surprised to see a second shooter. He pulls himse from the window, puts away his scope, and accelerates his exit.

Outside, we see the doorman drop both guns on the pile of bodies. He walks back toward us through the glass doors a makes his way through the building toward the service exi He sheds his uniform and stuffs it into a plastic bag.
his two parcels in hand, exits out the side door of the h and walks down the street.
now wearing rich man's sweats, hops off the loading dock, walks to a Lincoln Town Car, and drives off.
Martin rolls down FDR Drive in a Lincoln Town Car once ag on the cellular.
...Tell them that's not my problem.  I was paid for one job-- the cyclist--  not two. See you tomorrow, Marcella.
Wait. I have Mr. Grocer for you.
Patch him through.... Martin notices another Town Car appears in the next lane. recognize the Doorman behind the wheel, phone in hand. He GROCER.
What do you want?
I'm setting up a concern that would  enable those of us in our rarefied  profession to consolidate our efforts.
Like a union?
Like a club. Work less, make more.
Thank you, no.
We could be working together, making  big money, killing important people...  I'm willing to let you in on the  ground floor.
And you could be... sort of like...  a father figure to me.... Grocer ignores this.
It's a free-market evolution. You'll  wake up to it... c'mon Kid. We used  to run together when you were a  rookie. I don't want to run against  you. This thing's real. Everybody's  in.
Not me. So don't paw at me with your  dirty little guild.
I'm gonna get you, kid. Martin hangs up and pulls away.

Martin sits in first class, wiping his face and hands wit an airline hot towel. He folds the wet cloth and once aga speeds through the images from a thick stack of magazines He looks up as he hears PILOT V.O.  It's seventy-six degr and partly cloudy in Chicago this afternoon...
Martin walks into a sparsely furnished apartment. He wear drops his carry-on bag and briefcase in the hall.

Martin sits on a futon couch watching MTV with no sound. the coffee table in front of him is a phalanx of vitamin  bottles. Martin takes some capsules from each and washes  them down with a reddish-orange beverage.
Martin lies on his back on the hardwood floor. His eyes a closed and he wears a set of headphones as he absently ta his chest.
"Dear Alumni: Can you believe it's  been ten years? Where are you now...? After a moment, his eyes open, alerted. His head turns to the side, and his hands lightly cup the headphones.

from the headphones as it winds to a small metal box, wit one unmarked switch and one amber light- definitely not a walkman. The wire continues out of the other side of the  box, across the floor, connecting to a suction cup stuck the floor.
...Are you guiding an Outward Bound  canoe trip like Brook Stinson? Or  perhaps in charge of appearances for  the NFL like Leslie Gunther....?
draws a pre-cut section of the floor, the width of a penc and twice as long, by a string.

The greenish Starlight (night vision) image of a young, H MAN sleeping on his back, as seen from above. A fine thre snakes from behind CAMERA to just above the man's slack m We PULL BACK to reveal a Sony Watchman that holds the IMA KEEP PULLING to reveal Martin watching it as he maneuvers the thread down past the fiber-optic cable through the ho in the floor.
concentrates as he applies three drops of blue liquid on thread. As the drops run down along the thread through th floor, his attention shifts to the
The drops, huge in the foreground, become smaller as they make their way down the line toward the sleeping man.
...Could it be that you're like Chip  Longfellow, at the trade-relations  tank in Washington. Sandy Glasser  owns a cheese shop...!
adjusts the thread minutely with one hand, and lowers the fiber-optic cable with the other.
The face begins to fill the screen as the fiber-optic fol the drops toward it. Suddenly, the man snorts and turns h face...
It misses the man's mouth and hit's his cheek.
The man's eyes snap open in terror as he looks directly i CAMERA. His image falls away as the fiber-optic is jerked back up through the hole in the floor.
...Looking at yearbooks and pictures  evokes so many memories...!
(hushed)
Fuck!
stuffs the apparati into an open duffel bag, and flies ou of frame.
...Some good. Some bad. But all  interesting...

A BODYGUARD sits outside an apartment door. A muffled but dire scream is heard from within and he is on his feet, g in hand. An exit door in the hallway slams open revealing Martin, his gun already pointed at the Bodyguard. The  Bodyguard levels his at Martin.
Freeze! Police! The Bodyguard hesitates just long enough to get double-ta through the head.

...As a graduate of the class of  1984, you are someone special... Martin moves to the dead Bodyguard, and locates a retract key chain on his belt. He unreels the ring of keys and op the door. He lets the keys retract back to the belt and d him into the apartment.
Martin moves silently down the hall in a crouch. He comes the bedroom and slips across the threshold.
...Whenever news of you filters back,  the school is excited and proud of  your accomplishments...

Martin crouches down outside the bedroom door. He points gun at the door, and reaching up turns the knob. As the d opens, the Husky Man FIRES wildly over Martin's head. Mar returns with one shot to the hut which sits the man down the floor.

...We hope Grosse Pointe High prepared  you well to lead the kind of life  that makes an impact on the world... Martin kicks the gun away from the fallen man, and raises his barrel to the man's forehead.
...Remember, "there's no where you  can go that you haven't learned how  to go in time... It's easy..."
(in severe pain)
Whatever it is that I'm doing that  you don't like I'll stop doing it.
It's not me. Martin cocks the gun....
The perpetual sun shines down on a small lot of pre-fab o bungalows.
A small suite of dry-walled offices.
is stenciled on glass doors behind Martin who stands in f of a young woman reading from some kind of invitation. Sh is MARCELLA MAYES.
...So come on back to the old oak  tree, acorns. Signed, the reunion  committee." Marcella holds up the mauve envelope and smiles slyly. Fo the first time, Martin looks scared.
Throw that away.
This?
Don't tease me. You know what I do  for a living.
It's from one of those P.O. Boxes.  How was the trip?
Tedious. I now authorize you to throw  away all personal mail.
All of it?
And not show it to me. Ever again.
That's going to cost.
I'll pay. Martin begins to walk past her into his office, but Marce stops him.
They're not happy, sir.
I'm not happy.
They say their friend was suppose to  have a heart attack and die in his  sleep.
He didn't.
They blame you for the compromise.
And they want me to make up for it.
In Detroit. This weekend.
Tell them that's impossible. I need  my normal lead time.
They were very upset.
Would you describe their position as  inflexible?
Intractable, sir. You leave tonight. Marcella looks concerned.
And sir, I also get that broken- mirror, black-cat, Friday-the- thirteenth kind of feeling about  this one....
There's nothing to be done about it.
I liquidated the last account in  Zurich, and split it into two new  ones in Estonia.
Good. What else? Anything interesting?
Mmm, not really. But you're gonna  love this one. She hands him a piece of paper. He scans it.
Enough?
Never enough.
But it's a Greenpeace boat. It'd be  so easy. Martin looks at her wearily. He puts it into the paper  shredder at the side of her desk.
I have scruples. Next.

Paperwork on the Detroit thing. It's  a full dossier. Very comprehensive. She raises a thick brown dossier from the top of her desk and puts it down again. Martin moves through a door to hi private office.

Martin goes into his office and sits at his desk. On the  walls are a couple of boring prints of tallships. A books holds trappings of a loose attempt at a cover-- a few shi manifests, sealane tables, and other specialized referenc books on import/export. He sits and stares.
Time has passed, and Martin still sits at his desk massag his gums with a rubber-tipped dental pointer.
The dental tool jumps across the gaps between his teeth l a hummingbird.
(off-screen)
You should get going....
pulls back his jacket lapel and fits the utensil into a p protector that is also home to a toothbrush, emery board, tweezers, and comb. He stands and walks out of his office
Martin moves toward the door. As he passes Marcella she h him the mauve envelope and a travel portfolio.
Don't forget your identity.
See you next week. Martin stops short as he reaches the threshold. He holds the envelope, and stares a dagger through it. On his way  out, over his shoulder...
Tell Dr. Oatman I'm on my way.
Martin slouches on a leather couch. He holds the mauve  envelope, now open.
Why don't you want to go to your  high school reunion?

It's in Michigan. Honestly, what do  I have in common with those people?  Or with anyone? DR. OATMAN sits in the window. He is Kris Kringle-esque, wears a sheepskin vest, rough-hewn shirt, faded Levis, an old Frye boots. Oatman nods with the suave understanding a man happy to collect fifty thousand in fees before aski a tough question.
You went to school with these people.
Come on.

We've spent a lot of time discussing  those years. Remember we said that  fear is a transfer of the bodily  hurt associated by experience with  the thing feared, to the thought of  the thing. Thus we fear a dog without  distinctly imagining its bite.
Shouldn't you be taking notes?
Tell me about your vision of the  reunion.
Of a crowded gymnasium. The alumni below stops what they doing and look up at Martin, DRAWING GUNS OF ALL SHAPES A

head_text.subj: SIZES AND OPEN FIRE ON MARTIN. THE UNITED FORCE INSTANTLY
DISINTEGRATES, AND ALL 400 PEOPLE TURN THEIR GUNS ON EACH
OTHER. A BLOODBATH ENSUES. ONE ALUMNI SHOOTS HER OWN HEAD
OFF, ANOTHER MOWS DOWN THE BAR, ETC.

text: It'll be depressing.
How do you know?
I just know.
Say more.
They'll have husbands and wives and  children and houses and dogs....  made themselves a part of something.  And they can talk about what they  do. What am I going to say? (sarcastic)
"I killed the President of Paraguay  with a fork." Oatman twitches nervously, almost spilling his coffee.
You needn't be so frank with me about  your work.
Why not. I trust you. You couldn't  turn me in because of Doctor-Patient  privilege... and I don't want to be  "withholding"... and I know where  you live.
You know where I live?
We're both professionals, Oatman.

I think what you fear Martin is  domesticity. It's the greatest fear  that men have who belong to Western  Culture. It's centuries old. Like  King Phillip, in the 11th or 12th  century who decided one day that he  was so bored with his dreary life at  home with his wife he thought, "Well,  wouldn't it be great if we hit the  road and fought... oh... the  Saracens."  So he put the word out  and was amazed when a million men  signed up and all of them wanted to  go and fight in distant lands and do  terrible things to people rather  than stay at home with their families.
So you're saying that Ulysses-- everything he said to his queen when  he came back--everything was a lie?  He just wanted to fuck around?
Yes.
Mmm. Beat.
And how have you been feeling about  your... work lately?
Uneasy. Dispassionate. Bored. It's  just getting hard to go to work in a  good mood. I'm starting to think  I've been in the business too long.  Last week I did a guy younger than  me.
From the back of the darkened empty church, we see him mo the altar.  A priest in fact.
open the gilded doors to reveal the chalice. He removes i squirts a clear liquid into the cup, and swishes it out. returns the chalice to the cabinet.
The church seems to be purging itself  of it's pedophile.
Sits in the back pew of the church, now crowded for Mann. watches the PRIEST lift the chalice into the air, murmur prayer, and drink from it. The Priest collapses behind th altar.
It's a bull market.
The chalice bounces free from the Priest's hand as it hit the ground.
Anyway, that never use to happen. I  was always the prodigy. Now I'm just  one of the guys.
Maybe some of the discomfort you're  feeling is... guilt. Remorse. Over  the innocent people you've killed.
If I show up at your door, chances  are you did something to bring me  there. I don't care about that stuff,  anyway.
What stuff?
(dismissive)
Morality. Oatman's glad the session's just about over.
Go to your reunion, Martin. See those  people and discover what they mean  to you. Try not to kill anybody for  a few days, see how you feel.
If I get antsy I'll kill a few small  animals.
Now we're making progress.

Very dark. No pictures or plants. Almost no furniture, an what he does have is black. The only sign of life is a CA The cat watches on as Martin sorts through a cardboard bo finally coming to a photo album.
Meow.
Just a minute.

A teen-aged Martin Blank: shy boy with a nervous smile. H poses with his mother, an older woman with a kind smile.. but her eyes are dark; aged by a life of work and worry. the opposing page is a gilt funeral announcement that rea
turns the page.
A photograph of a tall, thin girl: a bright smile from wi a bulky winter coat. A girl he's always wondered about: D NEWBERRY. Handwritten on the photo in girlish loops: "Wou you rather...?!"
Meow!
Martin pulls himself away from the album and the cat foll him, moaning hungrily--

Food soon... Martin opens a restaurant-style refrigerator. It holds va bottles of vitamins, spirulina, wheatgrass, digestible  hydrogen peroxide, fluoride treatment, oxygenated mouth r and thirty cans of CATFOOD.
Tuna or liver?
Meow.
Tuna it is. He opens a can for the cat and a bottle for himself. Whil the cat eats, he returns to the cardboard box. Finds a  YEARBOOK. Flips it open....
A picture of a senior class "Blues Brothers" party: a gro of teens mug to the camera in Blues Brothers get-ups.  Sprinters race for a finish line, their chests stretching for the tape.
A more mature version of the girl in the album. Her name  appears under his picture...

Track light fills the gourmet-rustic kitchen. GROCER stan wearing a burgundy Fila sweat suit, pushing beets into a  vegetable juicer. Next to the juicer are piles of celery carrots, as well. A low-key BLIP is heard from another ro Grocer tops off the glass and takes it out of the kitchen
Grocer enters the main room of the villa-style A-frame. H moves to an antique oak desk and sits in front of a COMPU
"Click OK for remote access caller"
OK is clicked. "Availability for two days in Detroit area" "Terms"
"When" "Now" "OK/ FAX materials"

Grocer leans back in his chair and sips the juice. After moment, the FAX machine on the desk rattles. The computer beeps. "confirmation number of wire transfer#: AJ6687-OI99471" Grocer hits the return button after taking in the number. graphic appears: "Connection is terminated/ Status idle" Grocer's FAX begins to moan and chatter. Grocer raises hi juice glass to the computer in a lazy toast.

Martin reclines in first class, soaring toward the Midwes on the red-eye. He has already scanned his magazines and  they are piled in the empty seat next to him. He sets asi a Powerbar. Martin reads Kill Without Joy. After a moment he sets the book down and takes up Iron John.
At the edge of the airport bar sits LARDNER and MCCULLERS two Government Spooks, agency unknown. They are both in  blazers, no ties, early thirties, and they watch the pass crowd.
You always say that. You always say  that. I'm telling you, you never met  the man.
Seventeen months ago I was posting a  walk in Lisbon, and he was there. He  never saw me. But I saw him, though.
Lisbon?
In Portugal, yes. In the background, Martin passes by them as he walks down the hall. Without directly regarding him, the two stand,  drop some cash on the bar, and begin to leave.
Here's the news: He hasn't been in  Portugal since '90. I know that from  the file. Why don't you read the  file, man?
In fact, I think I talked with him,  in Bonn. Lardner can neither confirm nor deny this.
You always say that. You always have  to know everybody. Why don't I just  take the weekend off and let you  kill him. Since you two are so close. They exit.
Martin, in a black Lincoln Town Car, veers off of the air artery and on to a turnpike. The radio broadcasts the new
...with highs today in the upper  seventies. Related stocks on Wall  Street today as scandal continues to  rock the joint U.S.-Japanese Tech  Center...
blows past CAMERA and on down the road. After a beat, a m eighties Ford Country Squire station wagon follows, occup by two figures.
are Lardner and McCullers. They listen to the same broadc
...An unknown "whistle-blower" has  leaked a number of critical flaws in  the safety designs of next year's  models to authorities that could  cost millions in recalls....
flips through the dial, pausing on Rush Limbaugh who waxe fascistically.
Mein hero. ...and then turns the dial again and cuts in on "Armagedd Time," slow reggae vibe by The Clash.
Martin drives down the roadway... headlong into his past. Dig it...
Martin turns up the volume as he reacts to a familiar  voice....
(on radio)
--this is WFRN, all vinyl, all the  time. Oldies from the eighties. It's  a cold summer day in Grosse Pointe--
lit only by dime slivers of sunlight, in front of a  microphone. Stray, gossamer strands of hair hanging in he face move in front of her mouth as she speaks....
--and I'm ready for some good tunes  and angry talk. Or angry tunes and  good talk--
looking somewhere far away, beyond what is before him in windshield...
